deck.name: IT & Computer Science
deck.description: Essential vocabulary for software development, networking, cybersecurity and computer science.

cards.definition: a step-by-step procedure for solving a problem or performing a task
cards.context: The sorting algorithm runs in O(n log n) time.

cards.definition: Application Programming Interface — a set of rules that allows programs to communicate with each other
cards.context: We use a REST API to fetch data from the server.

cards.definition: the server-side part of an application that handles logic, databases and authentication
cards.context: The backend is built with Node.js and Express.

cards.definition: the client-side part of an application that the user interacts with directly
cards.context: The frontend uses React to render the UI.

cards.definition: an error or flaw in a program that causes it to behave unexpectedly
cards.context: We found a critical bug in the payment module.

cards.definition: a hardware or software component that stores data so future requests are served faster
cards.context: The browser cache reduces page load time.

cards.definition: delivery of computing services over the internet instead of local hardware
cards.context: We migrated our infrastructure to cloud computing.

cards.definition: a program that translates source code into machine code before execution
cards.context: The C++ compiler detected a syntax error on line 42.

cards.definition: Central Processing Unit — the main chip that executes instructions in a computer
cards.context: The CPU usage spiked to 100% during the benchmark.

cards.definition: an organized collection of structured data stored and accessed electronically
cards.context: User accounts are stored in a PostgreSQL database.

cards.definition: the process of finding and fixing errors in code
cards.context: Debugging took longer than writing the feature.

cards.definition: the process of releasing software to a production environment
cards.context: We automate deployment using a CI/CD pipeline.

cards.definition: Domain Name System — translates domain names into IP addresses
cards.context: The DNS server resolved example.com to 93.184.216.34.

cards.definition: the process of converting data into a coded format to prevent unauthorized access
cards.context: All passwords are protected with AES-256 encryption.

cards.definition: a specific URL where an API receives requests
cards.context: The /users endpoint returns a list of all registered users.

cards.definition: a network security system that monitors and controls incoming and outgoing traffic
cards.context: The firewall blocked the suspicious connection attempt.

cards.definition: a reusable set of libraries and tools that provides a structure for building software
cards.context: React Native is a popular framework for mobile apps.

cards.definition: a developer or role covering both frontend and backend development
cards.context: She works as a full-stack developer using Next.js.

cards.definition: a reusable block of code that performs a specific task
cards.context: This function calculates the total price including tax.

cards.definition: a distributed version control system used to track changes in source code
cards.context: We use Git to collaborate and manage branches.

cards.definition: HyperText Transfer Protocol — the foundation of data communication on the web
cards.context: The browser sends an HTTP GET request to load the page.

cards.definition: Integrated Development Environment — a software suite for writing, testing and debugging code
cards.context: VS Code is one of the most popular IDEs today.

cards.definition: a single pass through a set of instructions in a loop
cards.context: Each iteration of the loop processes one item in the array.

cards.definition: JavaScript Object Notation — a lightweight data-interchange format
cards.context: The API returns data in JSON format.

cards.definition: the core part of an operating system that manages hardware and system resources
cards.context: The Linux kernel handles memory allocation and process scheduling.

cards.definition: the time delay between a request and the corresponding response
cards.context: Low latency is critical for real-time multiplayer games.

cards.definition: a collection of pre-written code that developers can use to perform common tasks
cards.context: We imported a date library to handle time zones.

cards.definition: a hostname that refers to the current computer, usually resolving to 127.0.0.1
cards.context: The dev server is running on localhost:3000.

cards.definition: malicious software designed to damage or gain unauthorized access to a system
cards.context: The antivirus detected malware in the downloaded file.

cards.definition: a situation in version control where two changes to the same file cannot be automatically combined
cards.context: We resolved the merge conflict before pushing to main.

cards.definition: software that sits between the OS and applications, or between request and response in a server
cards.context: The authentication middleware checks the JWT token.

cards.definition: a self-contained unit of code that can be imported and reused
cards.context: Each feature is organized as a separate module.

cards.definition: a group of interconnected computers that can share data and resources
cards.context: The office network supports up to 200 devices.

cards.definition: Object-Oriented Programming — a paradigm based on classes, objects, inheritance and encapsulation
cards.context: Java is a language that heavily uses OOP principles.

cards.definition: software whose source code is freely available for anyone to view, modify and distribute
cards.context: Linux is the most well-known open source operating system.

cards.definition: system software that manages hardware and provides services for applications
cards.context: Windows, macOS and Linux are popular operating systems.

cards.definition: a tool that automates installing, updating and removing software packages
cards.context: We use npm as the package manager for our JavaScript project.

cards.definition: a numbered endpoint for network communication on a host
cards.context: The web server listens on port 443 for HTTPS.

cards.definition: a set of rules that governs how data is transmitted over a network
cards.context: HTTPS is a secure protocol for web communication.

cards.definition: a proposal to merge code changes from one branch into another, allowing review
cards.context: Please open a pull request so we can review your changes.

cards.definition: a request for data from a database or search engine
cards.context: The SQL query returned 1,500 matching records.

cards.definition: Random Access Memory — temporary storage that the CPU uses for active tasks
cards.context: The application requires at least 8 GB of RAM.

cards.definition: restructuring existing code without changing its external behavior
cards.context: We spent a sprint refactoring the authentication module.

cards.definition: a central location where code and its history are stored
cards.context: Clone the repository from GitHub to start contributing.

cards.definition: a web design approach that makes pages render well on different screen sizes
cards.context: Responsive design ensures the site looks good on mobile.

cards.definition: the period during which a program is executing, or the environment that runs it
cards.context: Node.js is a JavaScript runtime built on Chrome's V8 engine.

cards.definition: Software as a Service — a model where software is hosted in the cloud and accessed via subscription
cards.context: Slack and Google Workspace are popular SaaS products.

cards.definition: the ability of a system to handle increasing workload without losing performance
cards.context: We designed the architecture with scalability in mind.

cards.definition: Software Development Kit — a set of tools for building applications for a specific platform
cards.context: The Android SDK includes an emulator and build tools.

cards.definition: a computer or program that provides services or resources to other computers on a network
cards.context: The server handles thousands of requests per second.

cards.definition: Structured Query Language — a language for managing and querying relational databases
cards.context: She wrote an SQL query to join the users and orders tables.

cards.definition: Secure Shell — a protocol for securely connecting to a remote machine over a network
cards.context: I connected to the production server via SSH.

cards.definition: an error that occurs when a program uses more call stack memory than is available
cards.context: The recursive function caused a stack overflow.

cards.definition: the set of rules that defines the correct structure of code in a programming language
cards.context: Python uses indentation as part of its syntax.

cards.definition: a text-based interface for interacting with the operating system through commands
cards.context: Open a terminal and run npm install.

cards.definition: the process of evaluating software to find defects and ensure quality
cards.context: Unit testing covers individual functions in isolation.

cards.definition: the smallest unit of execution within a process
cards.context: The app uses multiple threads to handle requests concurrently.

cards.definition: a piece of data that represents authorization or identity
cards.context: The JWT token expires after 24 hours.

cards.definition: a typed superset of JavaScript that compiles to plain JavaScript
cards.context: We use TypeScript to catch type errors at compile time.

cards.definition: User Interface — the visual elements through which a user interacts with an application
cards.context: The UI was redesigned to improve accessibility.

cards.definition: User Experience — the overall experience a person has when using a product
cards.context: Good UX reduces friction and increases user retention.

cards.definition: a named storage location in memory that holds a value
cards.context: Declare the variable with let if its value will change.

cards.definition: a system that records changes to files over time so you can recall specific versions
cards.context: Version control lets us revert to any previous state of the code.

cards.definition: a software emulation of a physical computer that runs its own operating system
cards.context: We run the test suite inside a virtual machine.

cards.definition: Virtual Private Network — creates an encrypted connection over a less secure network
cards.context: Use the company VPN to access internal resources remotely.

cards.definition: an HTTP callback that sends real-time data to other applications when an event occurs
cards.context: The payment provider sends a webhook when a transaction completes.

cards.definition: Continuous Integration / Continuous Deployment — practices for automating build, test and release
cards.context: Our CI/CD pipeline runs tests on every pull request.

cards.definition: a lightweight, standalone package that includes everything needed to run a piece of software
cards.context: We deploy each microservice as a Docker container.

cards.definition: an architectural style where an application is composed of small, independent services
cards.context: Each microservice handles a single business capability.

cards.definition: hiding complex implementation details behind a simpler interface
cards.context: Good abstraction makes the codebase easier to maintain.

cards.definition: the maximum rate of data transfer across a network path
cards.context: Video streaming requires high bandwidth.

cards.definition: a data type that can only be true or false
cards.context: The function returns a boolean indicating success.

cards.definition: a unit of digital information equal to 8 bits
cards.context: A single ASCII character takes up one byte.

cards.definition: a blueprint for creating objects in object-oriented programming
cards.context: The User class defines properties like name and email.

cards.definition: Command Line Interface — a text-based interface for running programs and commands
cards.context: Use the CLI to scaffold a new project.

cards.definition: an external library or module that a project requires to function
cards.context: We updated all dependencies to their latest versions.

cards.definition: a set of practices that combines development and operations to shorten the release cycle
cards.context: The DevOps team automated the entire deployment pipeline.

cards.definition: a fixed-size value computed from input data, used for integrity checks or indexing
cards.context: Passwords are stored as bcrypt hashes in the database.

cards.definition: an OOP mechanism where a class derives properties and methods from a parent class
cards.context: The Admin class uses inheritance to extend the User class.

cards.definition: a numerical label assigned to each device connected to a computer network
cards.context: The server's IP address is 192.168.1.10.

cards.definition: a tool that analyzes code for potential errors and style violations
cards.context: The linter flagged an unused variable on line 17.

cards.definition: the actual data carried in a network request or message
cards.context: The POST request includes a JSON payload with user details.

cards.definition: Regular Expression — a pattern used to match and manipulate strings
cards.context: We use a regex to validate email addresses.

cards.definition: to generate and display visual output on the screen
cards.context: React re-renders the component when state changes.

cards.definition: Representational State Transfer — an architectural style for designing networked APIs
cards.context: The REST API exposes CRUD operations for each resource.

cards.definition: a device or module that directs data packets between networks or application routes
cards.context: The Express router maps URLs to controller functions.

cards.definition: the structure or blueprint that defines how data is organized in a database
cards.context: The database schema includes tables for users, posts, and comments.

cards.definition: the region of code where a variable is accessible
cards.context: Variables declared with let have block scope.

cards.definition: a design pattern that restricts a class to a single instance
cards.context: The database connection pool is implemented as a singleton.

cards.definition: a fixed time period in Agile during which specific work must be completed
cards.context: We plan two features for each two-week sprint.

cards.definition: protocols that provide encrypted communication over a network
cards.context: The website uses SSL/TLS to protect user data in transit.

cards.definition: a data structure that follows Last-In-First-Out order; also refers to a technology stack
cards.context: Our tech stack includes React, Node.js, and PostgreSQL.

cards.definition: the current condition or data of an application or component at a given time
cards.context: The component re-renders whenever its state changes.

cards.definition: a sequence of characters used to represent text in programming
cards.context: The function takes a string parameter and returns its length.

cards.definition: an ordered, immutable collection of elements
cards.context: The function returns a tuple of the x and y coordinates.

cards.definition: the extent to which a language prevents type errors
cards.context: TypeScript provides type safety by checking types at compile time.

cards.definition: Uniform Resource Locator — the address used to access a resource on the web
cards.context: Enter the URL in your browser to visit the website.

cards.definition: the process of verifying the identity of a user or system
cards.context: Authentication is handled via OAuth 2.0 tokens.

cards.definition: the process of determining what an authenticated user is allowed to do
cards.context: Authorization rules restrict admin pages to staff only.
